segment.source: Manage user accounts in Windows Store for Business (Windows 10)
segment.target: Manage user accounts in Windows Store for Business (Windows 10)

segment.source: Windows Store for Business manages permissions with a set of roles.
segment.target: Windows Store for Business manages permissions with a set of roles.

segment.source: Currently, you can assign these roles to individuals in your organization, but not to groups.
segment.target: Currently, you can assign these roles to individuals in your organization, but not to groups.

segment.source: Manage user accounts in Windows Store for Business
segment.target: Manage user accounts in Windows Store for Business

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 10 Mobile
segment.target: Windows 10 Mobile

segment.source: Windows Store for Business manages permissions with a set of roles.
segment.target: Windows Store for Business manages permissions with a set of roles.

segment.source: Currently, you can assign these roles to individuals in your organization, but not to groups.
segment.target: Currently, you can assign these roles to individuals in your organization, but not to groups.

segment.source: Why Azure AD accounts?
segment.target: Why Azure AD accounts?

segment.source: For organizations planning to use the private store feature with Store for Business, we recommend that you also configure cloud domain join.
segment.target: For organizations planning to use the private store feature with Store for Business, we recommend that you also configure cloud domain join.

segment.source: This provides a seamless integration between the identity your admin and employees will use to sign in to Windows and the Store for Business.
segment.target: This provides a seamless integration between the identity your admin and employees will use to sign in to Windows and the Store for Business.

segment.source: Azure AD is an Azure service that provides identity and access management capabilities using the cloud.
segment.target: Azure AD is an Azure service that provides identity and access management capabilities using the cloud.

segment.source: It is primarily designed to provide this service for cloud- or web-based applications that need to access your local Active Directory information.
segment.target: It is primarily designed to provide this service for cloud- or web-based applications that need to access your local Active Directory information.

segment.source: Azure AD identity and access management includes:
segment.target: Azure AD identity and access management includes:

segment.source: Single sign-on to any cloud and on-premises web app.
segment.target: Single sign-on to any cloud and on-premises web app.

segment.source: Works with multiple platforms and devices.
segment.target: Works with multiple platforms and devices.

segment.source: Integrate with on-premises Active Directory.
segment.target: Integrate with on-premises Active Directory.

segment.source: For more information on Azure AD, see About Office 365 and Azure Active Directory, and Intro to Azure: identity and access.
segment.target: For more information on Azure AD, see About Office 365 and Azure Active Directory, and Intro to Azure: identity and access.

segment.source: Add user accounts to your Azure AD directory
segment.target: Add user accounts to your Azure AD directory

segment.source: If you created a new Azure AD directory when you signed up for Store for Business, you'll have a directory set up with one user account - the global administrator.
segment.target: If you created a new Azure AD directory when you signed up for Store for Business, you'll have a directory set up with one user account - the global administrator.

segment.source: That global administrator can add user accounts to your Azure AD directory.
segment.target: That global administrator can add user accounts to your Azure AD directory.

segment.source: However, adding user accounts to your Azure AD directory will not give those employees access to Store for Business.
segment.target: However, adding user accounts to your Azure AD directory will not give those employees access to Store for Business.

segment.source: You'll need to assign Store for Business roles to your employees.
segment.target: You'll need to assign Store for Business roles to your employees.

segment.source: For more information, see Roles and permissions in the Store for Business.
segment.target: For more information, see Roles and permissions in the Store for Business.

segment.source: You can use the Office 365 admin dashboard or Azure management portal to add user accounts to your Azure AD directory.
segment.target: You can use the Office 365 admin dashboard or Azure management portal to add user accounts to your Azure AD directory.

segment.source: If you'll be using Azure management portal, you'll need an active subscription to Azure management portal.
segment.target: If you'll be using Azure management portal, you'll need an active subscription to Azure management portal.

segment.source: For more information, see:
segment.target: For more information, see:

segment.source: Add user accounts using Office 365 admin dashboard
segment.target: Add user accounts using Office 365 admin dashboard

segment.source: Add user accounts using Azure management portal
segment.target: Add user accounts using Azure management portal
